name: How To Survive: Third Person Standalone
description: Driven by community suggestion, 505 Games and EKO Software introduce you to a new single player 3rd person view experience that allows you to re-play the zombie crafting adventure "How to Survive" from a deeply immersive point of view.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: Intel Core 2 Duo or better Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Ati 5700 series/NVIDIA GeForce GT240 or equivalent Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 6 GB available space

Horrible and just awful... I actually enjoyed the original isometric game but it really doesnt translate well into 3rd person perspective like this. Maybe if this was some sort of added bonus version that came with the original as a package it would be worth a playthrough just to see how not to convert games just for it's own sake, but the fact that they charge you for it adds insult to injury.

Never getting really far in the original version of this game, i must say, HTS 3P is definately a grab. If you were one of the people who didnt like the camera view in the original, or is looking for a good zombie/crafting game, this is for you. However, it definately is a Progression by Error type of game...Unless thats just me. Playing on normal and having 2hrs in the game, ive probably died about 10-15 times, but because the checkpoint system is set up how it is, you are able to load the checkpoint, and basically be right where you died, except BEFORE it, so you can have a chance to do something else. The crafting in this game seems pretty awesome. I say 'seems' because ive only crafted a shotgun so far, but have the ability to craft molotovs, medpacks, and bows/arrows, also, there is a cutscene that shows the seemingly limitless possibilities to craft numerous types of weapons. I can't review the graphics or performance of the game, simply because im running it on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop on lowest res and low quality, but it runs smooth just based off that XD.   TL;DR : Pick up this game. Lots of crafting. Progression by Error WITH great checkpoints. Addicting.

At first, this looks like a good idea: take a good Top-down Hack-em-up and make it Third (almost First) person and it should be good, right?  No. Not at all. This game does not translate well to a 3d-perspective. Playability is dismal and leaves one wondering what is wrong with their keyboard. Targeting and striking is not precise and requires a fair amount of guesswork. You almost get the enjoyment of playing a game while being drunk, but without being intoxicated at all; it's the game, not you. The remainder of the game feels like a shadown of How to Survive or rather a beta test that needs work.  BUT... that's not really the problem with this putrid game.  Do you like Lagzilla? Do you? I don't. I could understand frame-rate issues if the details are set high and the PC is not up to it. However, a significant delay between pressing a key or button (1/2 second or more) is simply inexcusable. It is not limited to movement or attacks either, this wonderous feature also applies to mouse movement, rotating the camera, and even, as an added bonus, navigating the menu! Want to exit the game and be done with it? Well, be prepared to fight the interface to be free!  One of the charming aspects of this games 2d predecessor is the witty animations and narrations, subtly echoing the inane deliruim of the Pip-man character from the Fallout series. While these ran perfectly fine in that title, they don't here. Instead, we partake in a garbled mess of interlaced vomit smeared across the screen. If you think changing settings will fix this, think again. Perhaps you're the ingenious sort who fiddles with his computer and updates video codecs with great skill and precision. Well, fooled you twice, no dice for you! Perhaps you can just watch the original videos on some Youtube Lets Plays and fast-forward to the needed footage. It's not like you paid for this game or anything.  It's sad, really. The publishers did fair job on this games predecessor, How to Survive: Storm Warning Edition. It wasn't perfect, it wasn't even a 8/10 title, but it was acceptable, fun, and (most importantly) FUNCTIONAL. In this version, while we get to get a annoyed-parrot's eye view of the action, the daunting task of making the game work properly was clearly not a priority. In fact, it wasn't even on the list... not even the To-Do-When-Everything-Else-Is-Done List.  It dissapoints me to pay money for a game and find that the publisher has taken an 'Up yours' attitude towards its customers. The development clearly went straight from alpha directly to publication. There is no excuse for this rubbish.  Do not buy this game. Look at the screenshots, smile, and wonder 'What if?'. In fact, don't even accept this title for free or as a gift.  -2/10 (yes, that's a Negative two)

How to Survive is your quintessential zombie slaughter and escape style of game. The game takes place on a tropical island upon where you wake up on the beach surrounded by 'zombies' of various makes and models. You must then fight your way through the undead and the elements by crafting, looting and clearing. The idea holds up pretty well, even in the dirge of zombie-themed survival games simply because this one has more of an action-adventure feel. It's fast paced, gives you plenty to shoot at and crafting is simple and intuitive.  The survival mechanics are pretty basic: drink water, eat food and get some sleep/caffine each day. There's not much to it and it's pretty forgiving so I'm not sure it really adds much to the adventure, but at the same time it doesn't detract from it either. The crafting, on the other hand, is actually done quite well. Instead of a 'gather materials/find bench' approach, you actually combine parts into the finished product. I really like this approach. You don't put items in a grid or follow a recipe, you simply combine parts until you get a finished product. The order you do so is usually pretty lax too, so it serves as both an intuitive interface but also as clever inventory management as most things can be broken down again. Since you are limited to combinations the game accepts, it's perhaps a bit limiting since that serves as your guidance for doing so, but I found it more interesting than the typical crafting offered by other games.  The game itself is a 'update' from a top down twin stick shooter, and personally I think both versions work alright, though the world itself was clearly built from an overhead perspective so there is a conspicous lack of things such as indoor areas. Additionally there is a clear distinction between 'paths' and 'walls' and the perspective does make the island feel a lot smaller. However, the translation to 3rd person works. The biggest issue I ran into is simply trying to shoot an enemy very close to me. You'll absolutely want to switch to your melee weapons in these types of scenarios as the game does not have any aim assist, shoulder swapping or range compensation. It's a small hiccup though, I found it to be just as or even more enjoyable than the original.  The debate on whether it should be it's own product or a standalone aside, I think this game has gotten a far worse rap than it deserves, it's functionally and technically sound. It's recognizable among the endless hordes of similar titles thanks to some off-beat humor and despite being mindless fun, has quite a bit of content and challenge if you are up for the harder modes. If you are looking for a decent single player zombie survival experience with an action adventure feel, here you go: it's cheap, fun and not in early access.
